Why the name? This names was inspired by the creative revolution of the 1960's (aka Mad Men era), when art directors and copywriters were paired up. The idea of an advertising team made up of Art and Copy was born. Today, we’re in the midst of a second creative revolution, driven by technology. Code (i.e. engineering) is shaping how advertising is made and delivered. Summary Michal is a second-year MD candidate at Harvard Medical School. In summer 2014, she conducted orthopedic surgery research of the hand at Johns Hopkins exploring quality of life metrics in patients with trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis. At Harvard Medical School, Michal served as a Co-President of the LGBTQ and Allied Students at Harvard Medical School/Harvard School of Dental Medicine (LAHMS) and the Harvard Medical School Med Students for Choice (MSFC) chapter. In addition, she researches barriers to care for trans* patients at Fenway Health and co-chairs the Medical Education team at Harvard's Crimson Care Collaborative. She is a student member on the Massachusetts Medical Society's Committee on LGBT Matters. She is also actively involved in Harvard Medical School's curricular reform efforts through her work with the Health Equity in the Curriculum working group. 
 
Prior to Harvard Medical School, Michal served as an Allan Rosenfield Fellow at the Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR). Before that, she tracked Affordable Care Act implementation as a Research Assistant working on a grant from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. 
 
Through these experiences, Michal has developed a passion for the clinical research and advocacy work. Summary Michal is a second-year MD candidate at Harvard Medical School. Coordinated Successful Aging Intervention in multi-center, national study researching the 
effectiveness of lifestyle interventions in delaying and preventing disability. 
 
► Developed content for intervention protocol, created resource materials and conducted training for national and local interventionists. 
► Designed and led 450 workshops for 100 participants, aged 70-90 years, each with original presentations featuring over 120 speakers.  
► Planned and organized two national campaigns on hydration and sleep. 
► Composed 42 months of health newsletters and coordinated a senior health fair for participants. 
► Compiled, edited, printed and distributed participant life reflections in “Wisdom & Aging” booklet, “Our Stories” and “Faces of Aging” photo essay. Group Facilitator Stanford University, School of Medicine, Stanford Prevention Research Center 2008  –  2009  (1 year) Palo Alto, California, United States FRESH START Study, Stanford University/NCI  
Facilitated behavioral intervention program focusing on long-term lifestyle change to support 
weight loss and maintenance. 
 
► Led participants in choosing healthy eating options and adopting mindful (non-diet) stability skills. 
► Strengthened behavioral change using a participant-centered problem-solving model. 
► Increased participant physical activity by introducing a walking program using an electronic monitoring device. Health Educator Stanford University, School of Medicine, Stanford Prevention Research Center 2006  –  2008  (2 years) Palo Alto, California, United States Counseling Advice For Lifestyle Management, (CALM) Study, NIA/NHLBI  
Implemented telephone-based counseling sessions to deliver individualized health behavior modification programs focused on physical activity, nutrition and stress management to adults 50+.  
 
► Evaluated participants’ present habits and assessed willingness to make health changes. 
► Addressed resistance, helped participants identify potential barriers and develop goals and  
strategies using problem-solving techniques. 
► Followed-up and provided feedback relating to participant plans, actions and outcomes. Health Educator, Interventionist Stanford University, School of Medicine, Stanford Prevention Research Center 2004  –  2006  (2 years) Palo Alto, California, United States Lifestyle Intervention & Independence for Elders (LIFE-Pilot) Study, NIH/NIA  
Coordinated the Successful Aging Intervention in multi-center, national study, facilitating and 
presenting workshops for 50 participants, aged 70-90 years. 
 
► Scheduled over 50 speakers and facilitated 100 workshops - including original presentations, discussion groups and special sessions. 
► Developed a holistic successful aging “map” which was adopted study-wide to educate, 
inspire and empower older adults in making lifestyle choices to remain healthy and independent. 
► Generated list of speakers, community programs, activities and resources related to aging well. Group Nutritionist Stanford University, School of Medicine, Stanford Prevention Research Center 1997  –  2004  (7 years) San Jose, California, United States Women’s’ Health Initiative (WHI) Study, NIH/ NHLBI  
Led intervention groups in multi-center, national study, facilitating and presenting workshops, 
one-on-one consults and telephone follow-ups for 155 participants, aged 50-79. 
 
► Delivered a comprehensive program including behavioral skills, problem solving, stress reduction, label reading, cooking and taste testing. 
► Led discussions and activities related to dietary change to effect a diet low in fat and high in vegetables, grains and fruits, replacing refined foods. 
► Enhanced participants’ internal motivation to make health behavior changes, using a variety of 
negotiating strategies based on readiness to consider change.
